Award.AwardTitle: Some problems in geometric data analysis
Award.AbstractNarration:
The analysis of datasets is increasingly geometrical. In some applications, such as in the analysis of the cosmic web in astrophysics, this is arguably the most natural approach. In others, modeling datasets via geometric structures allows to bypass the use of functions, which are in general difficult to deal with in high-dimensions because of the so-called "curse of dimensionality". The project aims at making contributions in this general area of geometrical data analysis, and in particular in fields like clustering, dimensionality reduction, and surface estimation, via the development of new methodology and new theory.

Geometrical approaches to data analysis are well-established. Clustering, dimensionality reduction, and manifold/surface estimation, are well-developed, with ongoing work in the form of robust PCA, subspace clustering, manifold or surface clustering, manifold learning, geometric statistics, computational geometry, etc. The vast majority of this research is methodological or applied to a particular problem in a specific field, and theory is by and large lagging behind. This is, for example, the case in important areas such as subspace clustering, manifold embedding and sensor localization. This project has the ambition to contribute theoretical insights in those areas. While methodology tends to be well ahead of theory, good and timely theoretical analyses can shed some light on applied problems, and can sometimes inform the design of more effective methodology. And such methodology is missing in some areas of geometric statistics. Thus the project also includes the development of practical methodology that provably matches the minimax performance bounds available for the problem at hand, particularly in the areas of manifold estimation and the estimation of geometric characteristics of a distribution.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Multivariate analysis is a branch of statistical analysis, mostly exploratory in nature, which aims at organizing and finding useful and compact representations of the data --- which often comes in the form of data points in space.  Tasks addressed in this context include dimensionality reduction (to find a plane or surface that approximates the data), classical scaling (to embed the data in space based on pairwise dissimilarities), and clustering (to group the points together in a few meaningful clusters). 

 

In this area, approaches have been increasingly geometrical (and topological), and have been specifically developed to address the shortcomings of more traditional methods. For example, manifold learning (which consists in fitting a curved surface to data) evolved out of principal component analysis (which consists in fitting a flat surface to the data).

 

Multivariate analysis provides essential tools to researchers and engineers in very many areas --- any area dealing with data in the form of data points or abstract items related by a notion of dissimilarity. The award has funded further research into this area that has resulted in novel theory and methodology.

 

Indeed, this effort has resulted in a better understanding of how to estimate geometrical features of the data (including the volume and perimeter of the underlying support). A finer theory of shortest paths on a smooth surface, and their estimation and computation, was developed, which then motivated the proposal of a random model for paths with bounded curvature. The complex tasks of clustering planes (subspace clustering) and curved surfaces (surface clustering) were addressed, resulting in new methodology and theory. And some important methods for manifold learning (Isomap and MVU) were more finely examined, resulting in novel performance bounds for them.

 

Along the way, two postdocs, five doctoral students, one master’s student, and one undergraduate student, were educated and involved in these projects. This research has also helped the PI nurture a better and more comprehensive understanding of multivariate analysis as a whole, which will continue to transmitted in the context of a graduate course he teaches on the topic at his institution (Math 287B at UCSD).
